lecture 8: Operations on functions — Transformations: shifting, squeezing, reflecting, and composing functions

1. Motivation: Why Transform and Compose?

In modeling real‐world phenomena, we often need to tweak basic functions to fit data or combine them to capture complex relationships:

  • Audio volume control: stretching or squeezing the waveform.
  • Image translation: shifting pixel coordinates.
  • Signal inversion: reflecting a waveform.
  • Nested processes: feeding the output of one function into another (composition).

2. Transformations of the Graph

A transformation modifies the graph of a “parent” function f(x)f(x)f(x).

2.1 Shifting

  • Vertical shift: g(x)=f(x)+kg(x)=f(x)+kg(x)=f(x)+k
    • Up k>0k>0k>0, down k<0k<0k<0.
    • Example: g(x)=x2+3g(x)=x^2+3g(x)=x2+3 moves the parabola up 3 units.
  • Horizontal shift: g(x)=f(x−h)g(x)=f(x-h)g(x)=f(x−h)
    • Right h>0h>0h>0, left h<0h<0h<0.
    • Example: g(x)=(x−2)2g(x)=(x-2)^2g(x)=(x−2)2 moves f(x)=x2f(x)=x^2f(x)=x2 right 2 units.

Graphical summary

Transform Rule Effect
Up kkk f(x)+kf(x)+kf(x)+k Shift up kkk
Right hhh f(x−h)f(x-h)f(x−h) Shift right hhh

2.2 Stretching and Squeezing

  • Vertical stretch/compress: g(x)=a f(x)g(x)=a\,f(x)g(x)=af(x)
    • Stretch if ∣a∣>1|a|>1∣a∣>1, compress if 0<∣a∣<10<|a|<10<∣a∣<1.
    • Example: 2sin⁡x2\sin x2sinx is a vertical stretch of sin⁡x\sin xsinx by factor 2.
  • Horizontal stretch/compress: g(x)=f(bx)g(x)=f(bx)g(x)=f(bx)
    • Compress if ∣b∣>1|b|>1∣b∣>1, stretch if 0<∣b∣<10<|b|<10<∣b∣<1.
    • Example: sin⁡(2x)\sin(2x)sin(2x) is horizontally compressed by factor 12\tfrac1221​.

2.3 Reflection

  • Reflect about the x-axis: g(x)=−f(x)g(x)=-f(x)g(x)=−f(x)
    • Flips graph upside down.
  • Reflect about the y-axis: g(x)=f(−x)g(x)=f(-x)g(x)=f(−x)
    • Mirrors graph left to right.

Example:
Reflect f(x)=2xf(x)=2^xf(x)=2x about the y-axis to get g(x)=2−xg(x)=2^{-x}g(x)=2−x, which decays instead of grows.

3. Combining Transformations

Transformations can be chained. Always apply inside-the-function (horizontal) shifts/scales first, then reflections, then outside (vertical) scales/shifts.

Example:
Given
f(x)=x2,g(x)=−2 f(3(x+1))+4f(x)=x^2,\quad g(x)=-2\,f(3(x+1)) + 4f(x)=x2,g(x)=−2f(3(x+1))+4

  1. Inside: x→3(x+1)x\to 3(x+1)x→3(x+1) → shift left 1, compress horizontally by 1/3.
  2. Reflect x-axis and stretch vertically by 2.
  3. Shift up 4.

4. Composition of Functions

Composition feeds one function into another:

(h∘g)(x)=h(g(x)).(h\circ g)(x) = h\bigl(g(x)\bigr). (h∘g)(x)=h(g(x)).

  • Notation: h∘gh\circ gh∘g or h(g(x))h(g(x))h(g(x)).
  • Domain: those xxx for which g(x)g(x)g(x) is in the domain of hhh.

Real-world example:
Temperature conversion then rate calculation:

C(t)=59(F(t)−32),R(C)=2C+1(R∘C)(t)=2(59(F(t)−32))+1C(t)=\tfrac{5}{9}(F(t)-32), \quad R(C)=2C+1 \quad (R\circ C)(t)=2\bigl(\tfrac{5}{9}(F(t)-32)\bigr)+1 C(t)=95​(F(t)−32),R(C)=2C+1(R∘C)(t)=2(95​(F(t)−32))+1

4.1 Decomposing a Function

Given h(x)=2x+3h(x)=\sqrt{2x+3}h(x)=2x+3​, one composition is:

  • g(x)=2x+3g(x)=2x+3g(x)=2x+3
  • f(u)=uf(u)=\sqrt{u}f(u)=u​
  • Then h=f∘gh=f\circ gh=f∘g.

You can often find multiple decompositions by regrouping operations.

Regular Exercises

1. Graphing Transformations

Sketch f(x)=ln⁡(x)f(x)=\ln(x)f(x)=ln(x) and then sketch g(x)=−3 ln⁡(2(x−1))+2g(x)=-3\,\ln(2(x-1))+2g(x)=−3ln(2(x−1))+2. Label asymptotes and intercepts.

2. Chain of Transformations

Describe the sequence of shifts, stretches, and reflections to go from y=x3y=x^3y=x3 to y=4 (−(x+2)3)−1y=4\,( - (x+2)^3 ) -1y=4(−(x+2)3)−1.

3. Composition Practice

If f(x)=x2−1f(x)=x^2-1f(x)=x2−1 and g(x)=3x+2g(x)=3x+2g(x)=3x+2, find and simplify (f∘g)(x)(f\circ g)(x)(f∘g)(x) and (g∘f)(x)(g\circ f)(x)(g∘f)(x). Determine their domains.

4. Inverse & Composition

Let f(x)=2x+5f(x)=2x+5f(x)=2x+5. Find f−1(x)f^{-1}(x)f−1(x), then compute (f∘f−1)(x)(f\circ f^{-1})(x)(f∘f−1)(x) and (f−1∘f)(x)(f^{-1}\circ f)(x)(f−1∘f)(x), where f−1f^{-1}f−1 is the inverse of fff.

5. Transformation Proof

Let f(x)=x2,k=2,h=3f(x)=x^2, k=2, h=3f(x)=x2,k=2,h=3.
Prove that performing a horizontal stretch by factor kkk then a shift by hhh is not the same as shifting first then stretching (unless h=0h=0h=0).

6. Domain Composition

Given f(x)=x−1f(x)=\sqrt{x-1}f(x)=x−1​ and g(x)=ln⁡(x)g(x)=\ln(x)g(x)=ln(x), determine the domain of g∘fg\circ fg∘f and f∘gf\circ gf∘g, and explain any restrictions.
